title: IN SPITE OF • DESPITE • ALTHOUGH • EVEN THOUGH • THOUGH
subtitle: Structure • Examples • Explanation

sections.heading: IN SPITE OF
examples: I went jogging in spite of the rain.
In spite of being underage, Tina went to a bar.
I went to work in spite of my cold.
I arrived on time in spite of the bad traffic.
sections.explanation: Shows contrast: A happens even though B normally stops it. Meaning: 'B didn't matter.'

sections.heading: DESPITE
examples: I went jogging despite the rain.
Despite being underage, Tina went to a bar.
I went to work despite my cold.
I absolutely love Disney princesses despite the fact that I'm 30.
sections.explanation: Same meaning as 'in spite of.' Never use 'despite of.' 'Despite' is slightly more formal.

sections.heading: ALTHOUGH
structure: (can come at the beginning or middle of a sentence)
examples: Although England is famous for tea, many people love coffee.
We enjoyed the restaurant although the food wasn't very good.
Although Karin is only 12, she's very mature.
sections.explanation: Shows contrast between two ideas. Weaker than 'even though.'

sections.heading: EVEN THOUGH
structure: (can be at the beginning or middle)
examples: Even though Karin is only 12, she's very mature.
I watched the movie even though I don't like those kinds of films.
I bought new shoes even though I can't afford them.
He got the job even though he didn't have an interview.
sections.explanation: Meaning is the same as 'although,' but stronger contrast.

sections.heading: THOUGH
structure: often used at the end of a sentence in informal speech
examples: I had a good time at the restaurant. I didn't like the food though.
I didn't eat lunch. I had an apple though.
I left work early though my boss told me not to.
sections.explanation: Same meaning as 'although,' but more casual. Very common at the end in spoken English.

sections.heading: SUMMARY OF CONTRAST WORDS
examples: Even though → strongest
Although → normal
Though → informal
sections.explanation: Use 'in spite of/despite' with nouns/gerunds. Use 'although/even though/though' with clauses. Choose based on formality and contrast strength.
